item.title: SBS News in Easy English 5 December 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Revealed: The travel hotspots Australians are heading to this summer
item.description: Almost three-quarters of Australians will be heading on holiday this summer — but many are choosing to stay closer to home.

item.title: OpenAI invests in Australia & markets prepare for US and local interest rates decision
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Harry Morrow from Loftus Peak to find out more about OpenAI's new Australian intitiative including plans for a $7bn hyper data centre with NextDC; plus the day on the sharemarket with Omkar Joshi at Opal Capital Management.

item.title: US says there are opportunities to put AUKUS on 'strongest footing' after five-month review
item.description: Defence Minister Richard Marles said on Thursday that Australia is "working through" the review, which has has not been made public.

item.title: Uluru's Ayers Rock Resort sold to US-owned tourism company
item.description: Land and buildings at the resort will be transferred to Traditional Owners, the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara.

item.title: First time since 1974: Australia's FIFA World Cup 2026 opponents revealed
item.description: The most logistically complex World Cup in history will be held across the United States, Mexico and Canada from 11 June to 19 July.

item.title: First time since 1974: Australia's FIFA World Cup 2026 opponents revealed
item.description: The most logistically complex World Cup in history will be held across the United States, Mexico and Canada from 11 June to 19 July.

item.title: First time since 1974: Australia's FIFA World Cup 2026 opponents revealed
item.description: The most logistically complex World Cup in history will be held across the United States, Mexico and Canada from 11 June to 19 July.

item.title: Nightmares and PTSD: The reality of surviving a shark attack
item.description: Being bitten by a shark or other predator can leave lifelong scars. One survivor started a club for those who've lived to tell the tale.

item.title: For Australian retailers, Christmas cheer turns to fear as theft soars
item.description: As the festive shopping rush begins, vendors are bracing for a surge in shoplifting. Australia-wide, theft has hit a 21-year high. Experts say it’s part of a broader trend.

item.title: For Australian retailers, Christmas cheer turns to fear as theft soars
item.description: As the festive shopping rush begins, vendors are bracing for a surge in shoplifting. Australia-wide, theft has hit a 21-year high. Experts say it’s part of a broader trend.

item.title: 'Make memories’: the tragic reality of childhood DIPG and the new research giving families hope
item.description: An Australian cancer research centre has been awarded a 2.5 million dollar grant to further their research into one of the country 's deadliest brain cancers. Researchers at the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute in Melbourne hope to fast-track diagnosis and treatment options.

item.title: 'Deeply concerned': Australia sanctions top Taliban leaders
item.description: The federal government has similar sanctions in place for other countries, including Iran, Russia and North Korea.

item.title: The 'everyday' behaviour that has shop owners in Australia worried — and it's on the rise
item.description: As Christmas nears, increasing retail theft is costing profits and putting staff at risk. What's behind it?

item.title: How a 'weaker' La Niña could impact Australia differently this summer
item.description: La Niña is here, but not the one you're picturing. This year's event is shaping up to be "weak" — and the forecast points to a hotter, drier summer instead.

item.title: Australia up against World Cup co-hosts as the 2026 draw is made
item.description: The draw has been made for the 2026 FIFA World Cup - and Australia are up against the co-hosts.

item.title: The fake Indian wedding tying the knot between trend and tradition
item.description: The global, growing and glamorous trend of South Asian weddings — sans bride and groom — has landed on Australian soil.

item.title: Ethel took a job in Australia to support her family. She says she was 'left with nothing'
item.description: There are estimated to be more than 7,000 Pacific Island workers in Australia's agriculture and meat sectors at risk of exploitation.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Do oysters have ears? Dr Dominic McAfee shares a unique method for oyster regeneration
item.description: That's the sound of snapping shrimp - music to oyster ears. Dr Dominic McAfee has been playing this sound underwater to help regenerate natural oyster reefs. He's been doing this work for years, but recently, there's been an upswell in interest, as the South Australian government tries to increase resilience against a harmful algal bloom. The ongoing environmental crisis has killed hundreds of species and resulted in tens, possibly hundreds, of thousands of marine deaths. Dr McAfee says South Australia used to be home to huge oyster reefs, which would have curbed the intensity of the algal bloom because they naturally filter the water. He’s speaking here with SBS's Tee Mitchell, who started by asking about the role and extent of oyster reefs before colonisation.

item.title: Christmas lights return to Bethlehem for first time since Gaza war
item.description: A giant Christmas tree adorned with red and gold baubles stands in the West Bank city of Bethlehem for the first time since 2022.

item.title: 'A very painful day': India nightclub fire in Goa leaves 25 people dead
item.description: A fire in a nightclub in India's tourist hot spot of Goa has killed 25 people.

item.title: Minister defends taxpayer-funded trips as Coalition pushes for independent review
item.description: The communications minister is not indicating she will pay back any money as she comes under renewed fire for the cost of taxpayer-funded trips.

item.title: 'That's not neutrality': Protesters call on SBS to boycott Eurovision
item.description: Protesters have demanded SBS boycott the Eurovision Song Contest over Israel’s participation, but the public broadcaster said such a move would undermine its editorial independence.

item.title: What I didn’t expect when I used $11k from my super to freeze my eggs at 25
item.description: After being diagnosed with a condition that can affect fertility, Libby Wilson withdrew around $11k of her super to freeze her eggs.

item.title: 'It's nasty': Could this virus spark the world's next pandemic?
item.description: Epidemiologists are keeping a close eye on the H5 bird flu strains that are present in parts of the world.

item.title: Netanyahu says phase two of Gaza peace plan nears but key disputes remain
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated that progress toward the second phase of a US-backed plan to end the Gaza war is close.

item.title: Netanyahu says Israel nearing phase two of Gaza Ceasefire Plan
item.description: Israel is close to moving into the second phase of the Gaza ceasefire agreement, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cautioning that the next steps will be “more difficult” as tensions continue over Hamas’s disarmament, Gaza’s future governance, and the stalled two-state solution. Speaking in Jerusalem with German Chancellor Friedrich Merz, Mr Netanyahu received strong backing for Israel’s security while also confronting growing international scrutiny over alleged human rights breaches during the Gaza war.

item.title: Communities on high alert along NSW coast as firefighter dies battling blaze
item.description: Summer heat and high winds have fuelled a dangerous weekend of bush and grass fires across New South Wales, leaving more than 20 homes destroyed and claiming the life of a firefighter. The man died after being struck by a falling tree late Sunday while battling a blaze near Bulahdelah, with Premier Chris Minns saying the loss is devastating. Conditions eased by Monday, but authorities say nine fires remain uncontained across the state.

item.title: Energy bill rebates to be axed in cost of living relief 'shift'
item.description: Treasurer Jim Chalmers said tax cuts will instead help Australians to pay electricity bills and meet other cost of living pressures.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 8 December 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Markets brace for global interest rate decisions
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Luke McMillan from Ophir Asset Management about the day's sharemarket action including how the market is positioning itself ahead of key interest rates decisions out of the US and Australia.

item.title: 'Really nasty': The Christmas mistake Australians make — and what to do instead
item.description: And it's not the only handy tip to know while planning your Christmas spread.

item.title: Australia's teen social media ban: Here are all the key details
item.description: Platforms face up to $49.5 million in fines if they do not take "reasonable steps" to prevent under-16s from holding an account.

item.title: 'Six-foot-high pile': The unwanted fast fashion overwhelming op shops
item.description: Australians feel good donating clothes, but donation bins are being flooded with fast fashion and soiled items — and it’s costing op shops.

item.title: Tsunami warning lifted after magnitude-7.5 earthquake strikes Japan
item.description: The tremor struck off Japan's north-eastern coast about 11.15pm local time, prompting warnings — later lifted — of waves up to three metres high.

item.title: Tsunami warning lifted after magnitude-7.5 earthquake strikes Japan
item.description: The tremor struck off Japan's north-eastern coast about 11.15pm local time, prompting warnings — later lifted — of waves up to three metres high.

item.title: European leaders back Zelenskyy at ‘crucial time’ for Ukraine
item.description: European leaders have met Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in London amid growing US pressure for a proposed peace deal with Russia.

item.title: How the Thailand-Cambodia conflict went from Trump-backed ceasefire to airstrikes
item.description: Border clashes between the two countries have erupted, months after they signed a US-brokered ceasefire. But why has the fighting reignited?

item.title: One year after Al-Assad's fall: Syria's journey towards a new future
item.description: Syria's President is calling for Syrians to help the country become an advanced nation, as it celebrates one year since the fall of of former President Bashar al-Assad. Thousands of Syrians have taken to the streets to celebrate, waving the country’s new green flag , which for years was used by opposition forces during an uprising that became a civil war.

item.title: First Karen lost her mum. Then the fires came and burned all the memories
item.description: Fires are burning across Tasmania and NSW, with dozens of homes destroyed and critical infrastructure damaged.

item.title: One of the best meteor showers peaks this weekend. Here's how to watch it from Australia
item.description: Australia will enter a peak Geminids window this weekend as moonless skies promise one of the strongest meteor displays of the year.

item.title: Reserve Bank governor's warning about interest rates next year
item.description: Major banks and economists broadly predicted the cash rate would remain at 3.6 per cent.

item.title: 'Frightening': UN human rights team blocked from NT prisons and youth detention centres
item.description: A United Nations working group has been barred from accessing youth prisons, detention centres, and watch houses in the NT.

item.title: AUSMIN talks in Washington confirm AUKUS is progressing
item.description: Top security officials from the United States and Australia have met in Washington, confirming that the AUKUS security pact is moving "full steam ahead," despite the Pentagon's five-month review of the deal remaining secret. Both nations emphasised increased defence spending, critical minerals cooperation, and greater burden-sharing from allies to confront growing Indo-Pacific tensions.

item.title: No more interest rate cuts: the RBA's warning
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Goncalves speaks with Paul Bloxham from HSBC and Stuart Roberts from Stocks Down Under about why the RBA decision to leave interest rates on hold at its December board meeting and the increasing chance the next move in rates will be up, not down.

item.title: 'Profound shock': Family honours experienced firefighter killed in the line of duty
item.description: The 59-year-old was helping lead the charge against the Bulahdelah fire when he was killed.

item.title: The global fault lines emerging over Australia's social media ban
item.description: While Australia's world first under-16s social media ban is domestic in scope, its diplomatic implications appear to be far-reaching.

item.title: Trump renews attacks on 'weak' Europe as he pressures Ukraine to hold wartime elections
item.description: Donald Trump listed countries including Britain, France, Germany, Poland and Sweden that he said were being "destroyed" by migration.

item.title: At least two properties damaged as firefighters battle Tasmania bushfire
item.description: Local residents have been evacuated, as a fire threatens several communities on the east coast.

item.title: 'It won't be perfect': Albanese hails social media ban as it faces 'teething issues'
item.description: Enforcement challenges emerge as the social media ban takes effect, while the eSafety boss compares it to gun reform and predicts others will follow.

item.description: A year after clearing parliament, the teen social media ban finally took effect. But its debut was not without issues.

item.title: US could ask Australian tourists to submit five years of social media history
item.description: The proposal would expand existing Electronic System for Travel Authorisation requirements to include personal data spanning years.

item.title: 'Profoundly distressing milestone': Indigenous deaths in custody highest in 45 years
item.description: Grim figures reveal 33 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people died in custody in 2024-25 — the highest number since 1980.

item.title: Evidence reveals humans started fire-making 400,000 years ago after landmark UK find
item.description: The discovery pushes back global fire-making timelines and suggests our ancestors transported materials, such as iron pyrite, to spark flames.

item.title: Evidence reveals humans started fire-making 400,000 years ago after landmark UK find

item.description: The seizure marks an escalation in tensions in the region, where a large US military presence has built up in recent weeks.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 11 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Venezuela calls oil tanker seizure international piracy
item.description: President Donald Trump says US forces have seized the largest oil tanker ever intercepted off Venezuela’s coast, escalating Washington’s maritime campaign against vessels it claims support Nicolás Maduro or drug smuggling operations. Venezuela's government has accused the US of theft and international piracy. It has previously said it believes the United States is trying to depose President Maduro.

item.title: DRC & the Thai-Cambodia border wars, Syria a year after Assad & Trump finally gets his peace prize... sort of
item.description: Ceasefires are collapsing from Southeast Asia to eastern DRC, with civilians once again bearing the brunt of diplomatic failure. Plus, one year after the fall of the brutal Assad regime, are Syrians any better off? And FIFA honours President Trump – but is the prize an own goal?

item.title: 'Repugnant' text messages highlighted in NT's appeal of fatal hit-and-run sentence
item.description: The case of a driver who received a 12-month community corrections order for a fatal hit-and-run is back before the courts.

item.title: 'Is this actually helping?' How Trump's tourist disclosure plan would affect Australians
item.description: The US appears to be cracking down on speech criticising the government but experts say Australians may not have much to worry about.

item.title: US cuts rates as Australia's economy loses jobs
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Darren Thompson from Equity Trustees and Diana Mousina from AMP about the impact lower US interest rates and today's local labour force data is having on the sharemarket and what it means for local rates.

item.description: The Cronulla riots prompted a national reckoning on racism. How have things changed in the two decades since?

item.title: Joyce to the world: Our big Political Christmas wrap up
item.description: In the final episode for 2025, Elfy and Rania take a trip down memory lane looking at what happened in the federal election, some of the silliest moments of the year and a certain portrait of an ex Prime Minister Elfy hasn't gotten to talk about yet.

item.title: 'Extortionate': Why fans are calling for an 'immediate halt' to FIFA World Cup ticket sales
item.description: A fan group has sharply criticised the "astronomical" cost of tickets to next year's event.

item.title: Zelensky says Ukraine needs security guarantees before any vote
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says his government has spoken with the United States about possible security guarantees for Ukraine. He says those security guarantees would be impossible without support from the US, Europe and all members of the coalition of the willing, including Australia and New Zealand.

item.description: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado emerged in Norway after missing her award ceremony.

item.title: Trump threatens land invasion of Venezuela
item.description: The United States has defended the seizure of a Venezuelan oil tanker as a major US naval build-up in the region continues. Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has described the seizure as illegal with the US also imposing further sanctions on relatives of Maduro and other targetted naval vessels.

item.description: ASX soars to a four week high as investors eye Santa rally. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Marcus Bogdan from Blackmore Capital about what's driving the sharemarket and whether to expect the so-called Santa rally.

item.description: Life for Palestinian farmers living in the West Bank has become fraught, with rising attacks on crops and property by settlers.

item.title: The gift of mobility: How Des has changed 12,000 lives
item.description: A wheelchair can be life changing for people with disability. And that’s motivated a group of volunteers in Australia to turn old bicycles into wheelchairs, for charities worldwide.

item.title: 'Personal blessing': King Charles reveals cancer treatment can be scaled back
item.description: Charles, 77, had been receiving treatment after he was diagnosed with an unspecified form of cancer last year.

item.title: A plan for your home and a plan for your holiday: experts warn to prepare for further destructive fires
item.description: In recent weeks, bushfires have claimed homes and property on the New South Wales mid-north coast, in Geraldton in Western Australia and in Tasmania's east. Experts are warning this is only the beginning of the fire season and anyone travelling for the holidays needs to be aware and prepared when they're away from home.

item.title: 'Everybody knew this man': Trump says new photos of him with Epstein are 'no big deal'
item.description: Democrats released 19 new images of the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey ‍Epstein with several high-profile figures.

item.title: Thailand vows to keep fighting at Thai-Cambodian border until threats end
item.description: A ceasefire was signed in October, but border clashes between the Southeast Asian countries have reignited in recent days.

item.title: Amnesty International: Hamas committed war crimes in southern Israel
Tom Silvagni can now be named in the press. How do suppression orders work?
item.description: Once known as a 'high-profile' man guilty of two counts of rape, the media can now report Silvagni's name.

item.title: 12,000 lives changed: How a workshop is helping the most vulnerable with unwanted bikes
item.description: From abandoned bikes to functioning wheelchairs, a Gold Coast-based workshop is creating new possibilities for people with mobility challenges.

item.title: Amnesty International finds Hamas committed crimes against humanity on October 7
item.description: As part of its investigation, Amnesty interviewed 70 people, including survivors and victims' families, and visited some attack sites.

item.title: 'Hopeful for the future': Celebrations kick off as Victorian Treaty becomes law
item.description: First Nations people have welcomed the formal start of Victoria’s landmark Treaty, marked by a public concert in Melbourne.

item.title: St Kilda penguins 'weird' ticketing system forces visitors into months-long wait
item.description: St Kilda's penguin-viewing ticket system is frustrating visitors, as spots fill up fast and no-shows leave gaps, prompting calls for improvements.

item.title: 'Dignified retirement': What happens to the whales left behind when marine parks close?
item.description: Marine parks around the world have closed their doors in the wake of laws to address cruelty concerns. What about the animals left behind?

item.title: These Americans moved to Australia — but can't escape US politics
item.description: As interest in US politics surges and Australians' views shift for the worse, Americans reflect on what it's like to be an expat down under.

item.title: New electric air taxi prototype released
item.description: A company in the UK has unveiled a new prototype electric air taxi, promising to bring urban air transport to the masses. It's the next step in a globally burgeoning industry, for which the Australian aviation regulator is already planning. But there are many challenges lie ahead.

item.title: Two US soldiers and an interpreter killed in Syria ambush attack
item.description: Donald Trump has vowed to inflict "very serious retaliation" after an Islamic State ambush in Syria that killed three Americans.

item.title: Supermarket giants face $10 million fines over price gouging
item.description: Shoppers have been promised a fairer price at the checkout under laws to crack down on purported price-gouging by major supermarkets.

item.title: 'He took all my wages': How visa rules can expose migrant women to family violence
item.description: A Thai woman's harrowing story shows how migrant women are vulnerable to particular forms of family violence.

item.title: Attorney-General Michelle Rowland to repay 2023 family trip as expenses scandal grows
item.description: The treasurer on Sunday rejected calls for Rowland to resign amid growing scrutiny on politician's spending.

item.title: 'Deeply disturbed': Angry fans vandalise stadium as Messi's India tour turns into chaos
item.description: State chief minister Mamata Banerjee said she was "disturbed" and "shocked" at the mismanagement.

item.title: Paleo diets sell the idea of 'eating like our ancestors'. Here's what they actually ate
item.description: A new study by Australian and Canadian archaeologists proves what our ancestors really ate: everything.

item.title: Why Sara and Issam still can't go to Cronulla beach 20 years after the riots
item.description: Australia's racial discrimination commissioner is warning that the factors that fomented the Cronulla riots are still in play today - and that a similar racial brawl could occur again.

item.title: INTERVIEW: SBS speaks to Human Rights Commissioner as UN blocked from inspecting detention facilities
item.description: This week, human rights experts from United Nations Working Group on Arbitrary Detention were blocked from inspecting detention facilities in the Northern Territory and West Australia. As they wrapped up a 12-day tour of facilities across the country, preliminary findings raise substantial concerns around the over-representation of First Nations people, punitive policies that target children, rising rates of remand and mandatory detention, among other issues. The federal immigration detention regime was also found to contravene fundamental international human rights norms - including the Commonwealth's recent deal with Nauru to deport stateless people. Australia’s Human Rights Commissioner Lorraine Finlay says the findings show Australia is not complying with key international human rights commitments it has made to the world. She’s speaking here with Tee Mitchell.

item.title: Wanted in Hong Kong, now this China critic's wife is being targeted in Australia
item.description: Ted Hui, who lives in Australia in exile from Hong Kong, described the incident targeting his wife as "immoral".

item.title: What we know so far as NSW Police declare Bondi shooting terrorist incident
item.description: At least 16 people have been killed after gunmen opened fire at a crowd at Bondi Beach with footage showing a man disarming one of the gunmen.

item.title: Mary gave birth to her son in Australia. But he has no valid legal status
item.description: There's a growing number of undocumented children in regional Australia, born to disengaged migrant workers who have no visa.

item.title: What we know so far about the alleged Bondi Beach gunmen
item.description: While a motive is still unclear, police have revealed fresh details about the pair who mounted the terror attack at Bondi Beach.

item.title: Pakistani man falsely identified as alleged Bondi Beach gunman says he is 'scared'
item.description: A Sydney man of Pakistani origin says he's been targeted with abuse by people falsely accusing him of being one of the alleged gunmen in the Bondi Beach shooting.

item.title: 'A dark day in our nation’s history': Australia reels after Bondi Beach mass shooting
item.description: Police have declared a mass shooting at Bondi Beach on Sunday a terrorist attack, after two gunmen opened fire on hundreds of people gathered for a Hanukkah celebration. At least 16 people have been killed, including a child, in Australia's deadliest mass shooting since the 1996 Port Arthur massacre. The event has prompted global condemnation, heightened security at Jewish sites, created fear among communities and renewed calls from leaders to confront hate and stand in solidarity with the Jewish community.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 15 December 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'Not a blame game': Antisemitism envoy responds to Bondi attack, following Netanyahu snipe
item.description: Jillian Segal says part of her plan to combat antisemitism "can and should be accelerated".

item.title: 'Light a candle': How you can help after the Bondi Beach attack
item.description: Australians are coming together after Sunday's Bondi Beach attack. This is what you can do to help.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Jillian Segal, Special Envoy to Combat Antisemitism
item.description: Leaders of Australia's Jewish community have condemned the mass shooting on Bondi Beach. The shooting took place as people gathered for Chanukah by the Sea, a community event to celebrate the first day of Hanukkah. 15 people are dead and one of the two gunmen was also killed. A statement from the Jewish Council of Australia says the organisation is horrified and shaken. Jillian Segal is Australia's Special Envoy to Combat Antisemitism. She's been speaking to SBS Chief Political Correspondent Anna Henderson

item.title: Albanese sets 'immediate' gun control priorities following Bondi Beach terror attack
item.description: A crackdown on 3D-printed weapons and firearm limits has been flagged, and citizenship requirements for ownership could also be examined.

item.title: Tributes paid following death of director Rob Reiner and his wife Michele
item.description: Barack Obama said the actor and director's "achievements in film and television gave us some of our most cherished stories on screen".

item.title: These are the victims of the Bondi Beach terror attack
item.description: Funerals have commenced for the 15 people killed in a terror attack at Bondi Beach.

item.title: These are the victims of the Bondi Beach terror attack
item.description: Funerals have commenced for the 15 people killed in a terror attack at Bondi Beach.

item.title: Hong Kong court convicts pro-democracy tycoon Jimmy Lai in national security trial
item.description: The Australian government said it was "deeply concerned by the guilty verdict handed down to Jimmy Lai in Hong Kong".

item.title: Which supermarket has the cheapest groceries? Choice reveals its latest price check
item.description: There's one supermarket where a basket of groceries is significantly cheaper than its competitors, according to a new survey.

item.title: Albanese visits 'humble' Ahmed Al-Ahmed after Bondi hero speaks from hospital
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has visited Bondi hero Ahmed Al-Ahmed in hospital, calling him the "best of our country".

item.title: Australia marks Hannukah, mourns Bondi Beach victims | Morning News Bulletin 16 December 2025
item.description: The nation mourns as ceremonies mark Hannukah and remember the victims of the Bondi Beach terror attack; Ukraine's President Zelenskyy is set to resume talks with US envoys in Germany; And in sport, Pat Cummins calls for blood donations as sporting organisations express support for the Jewish community.

item.title: INTERVIEW: What needs to be done about our gun laws?
item.description: The Bondi Beach shooting has seen state, territory and federal politicians agree that Australia's already stringent gun laws need to be reviewed and strengthened. The National Firearms Agreement was introduced after the 1996 Port Arthur massacre to standardise rules about who could own a gun - and why. But experts on firearms legislation say some holes in the rules have become apparent. In New South Wales, applications to have a firearms licence are handled by the Gun Registry - which came under intense scrutiny after a tragic murder suicide in 2018, when an estranged father, John Edwards, fatally shot his teenage children. He had a history of domestic violence which hadn't been flagged to the Gun Registry. Not all the changes recommended after the Edwards inquest have been implemented. Deborah Groarke spoke to Maya Arguello who's a law and criminology expert at the Swinburne University of Technology.

item.title: 'We will not give in to fear': Vigils held across Australia to honour victims of Bondi terror attack
item.description: "We gather not in fear, but in strength," Rabbi Gabi Kaltmann told the crowd at Melbourne's Pillar of Light festival.

item.title: Six still in critical condition after Bondi attack | Midday News Bulletin 16 December 2025
item.description: Six still in a critical condition after Sunday's Bondi attack; Donald Trump slammed for his response to the murder of US director Rob Reiner; Melbourne Renegades off to a winning start in the Big Bash League.

item.title: 'Feel like such a hero': The Australians who shattered blood donation records
item.description: Australians have broken national blood donation records as some centres are booked up until the end of January.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 16 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Donald Trump sues the BBC, seeking billions in damages
item.description: The BBC apologised to the US president last month, but said it strongly disagreed that there were grounds for a defamation claim.

item.title: Light over darkness: the global Jewish community unites in tragedy
item.description: .A mass shooting at one of Australia's most famous beaches, targeting revellers at a Jewish holiday celebration, has generated shock and grief around the world. As condolences pour in, the Jewish diaspora and supporters have held vigils for those impacted by the tragedy -and a message of defiance against hate.

item.title: Alleged Bondi gunmen travelled to Philippines, 'aligned' with terrorist group, police say
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said on Tuesday the attack appeared to be "inspired by" the self-proclaimed Islamic State (IS) group.

item.title: More details emerge about extremist links of Bondi gunmen | Evening News Bulletin 16 December 2025
item.description: More details emerge about the background of the Bondi shooters; Donald Trump files a lawsuit against the BBC for their January 6 documentary; Just two changes for Australia ahead of the third Ashes test in Adelaide.

item.title: Donald Trump condemned for 'disrespectful' attack on Rob Reiner after director's death
item.description: Trump mocked Rob Reiner in a social media post after the director-actor and his wife Michele were found dead.

item.title: CBA & NAB predict February rate rise
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Jonathan Shead from State Street Investment Management about the day's market action including where interest rates are going and the opportunities for investors in 2026.

item.title: 'Different blind spots': Where are the gaps in Australia's gun laws?
item.description: The Bondi Beach massacre has renewed focus on Australia's gun laws, nearly three decades after the Port Arthur reforms.

item.title: Opposition puts migration policy on ice after Bondi Beach massacre
item.description: The Opposition will instead prioritise the formation of an antisemitism and counter-terrorism taskforce.

item.title: Amandeep ate a kebab as the sun set — then helped stop one of the alleged Bondi shooters
item.description: One of the many heroes who sprang into action after Sunday's attack says "now, more than ever, we need each other".

item.title: I have never earned more money, but I've never felt more broke
item.description: Chris Booy works three jobs. Despite this, he says that the Great Australian Dream of owning a home is feeling increasingly out of reach.

item.title: Government and Opposition work on plans to combat antisemitism | Morning News Bulletin 17 December 2025
item.description: The Government and Opposition work on plans to combat antisemitism following the Bondi terror attack; Zelenskyy says a deal to end nearly four years of fighting in Ukraine could be finalised within days; and in cricket, extra security expected at the third Ashes Test in Adelaide.

item.title: 'Act of war': Trump orders blockade of 'sanctioned' Venezuela oil tankers
item.description: Donald Trump appears to be ramping up pressure on Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro, whom he called "illegitimate".

item.title: First funerals held for victims of Bondi mass shooting | Midday News Bulletin 17 December 2025
item.description: The government working on plans to combat antisemitism following the Bondi terror attack; New research links cancer rates in Victoria with countries of origin; Chelsea book a spot in the League Cup semi-finals.

item.title: Is gun law debate a distraction from dealing with antisemitism?
item.description: The deadly Bondi mass shooting has intensified the national debate over Australia's gun laws. However, some prominent figures, including former Prime Minister John Howard, caution against letting the debate be diverted from the growing threat of antisemitism. So what are the opposing arguments from gun control advocates and pro-gun lobbies on whether current laws are adequate? The tragedy is fuelling a controversial political discussion around immigration and Australian values.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 17 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Ukraine peace talks pick up momentum after high-level Berlin meeting
item.description: High-level diplomatic talks aimed at ending the war in Ukraine are gaining momentum, with United States and European leaders hoping to secure a path to peace before Christmas. US President Donald Trump says negotiations on a draft peace plan have made significant progress. While Ukraine has welcomed the proposal, key issues remain unresolved, including the future of Russian-occupied territory and security guarantees to prevent renewed aggression.

item.title: Frydenberg lashes Albanese and says Bondi terror attack 'greatest stain on the nation'
item.description: Treasurer Jim Chalmers said he took his predecessor's views "seriously" and the government would "take suggestions from him".

item.title: NSW parliament to be recalled over 'urgent' gun reform and updated protest laws
item.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns said parliament will be recalled next week to debate a multi-faceted gun reform bill.

item.title: The self-proclaimed Islamic State group is active globally. Where is it located now?
item.description: Two flags linked to the self-proclaimed Islamic State group were found in the car used by the alleged shooters during Sunday's attack at Bondi Beach.

item.title: NSW parliament to be recalled over gun, protest laws | Evening News Bulletin 17 December 2025
item.description: The New South Wales parliament to be recalled after the Bondi attack; The Venezuelan government designated a foreign terrorist organisation; Usman Khawaja in form for Australia on day one of the Adelaide Ashes test.

item.title: Murders, terrorism: Dozens of charges laid against alleged 24-year-old Bondi gunman
item.description: Naveed Akram was shot by police at the scene and spent days in a coma before being charged.

item.title: Second Middle Eastern man tackled one of the Bondi gunmen but was then attacked himself
item.description: On the 14th of December, as an antisemitic mass shooting targeted a Hanukkah festival at Bondi Beach, several heroes emerged, most notably Ahmed al-Ahmed, a Muslim man of Syrian origin who courageously disarmed one of the attackers. But he was not the only Middle-Eastern Muslim to risk his life to put a stop to the attack. There was another Middle-Eastern Muslim man who risked his life to disarm the other shooter. However, his lawyer says due to his Middle-Eastern appearance and all-black attire, he was thought to be one of the shooters. As a result, he was shot at by police, then set upon by a small crowd of people.

item.title: MYEFO inflation implications & Westpac cancels 2026 rate cut call
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Shane Oliver from AMP about the implications the government's Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook will have on inflation as Kyle Rodda from Capital.com looks through the day's sharemarket action including Westpac's change of heart on interest rates

item.title: Government deficit figure has improved, but fiscal restraint important
item.description: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has unveiled a mid-year budget update marked by fiscal restraint, highlighting a $5.4 billion improvement to the deficit alongside critical new funding for the CSIRO and community security. However, the outlook remains fraught as rising inflation threatens real wage growth and persistent spending pressures in childcare and the NDIS continue to squeeze the bottom line.

item.title: How does your day compare? Here's how Australians are spending their time
item.description: Almost 10,700 Australians were surveyed, revealing both insights and disparities in daily life.

item.title: Cricket shirts and fake Hanson quotes: How false information spread after the Bondi attack
item.description: Misinformation and disinformation have been circulated widely since Sunday's massacre.

item.title: Cricket shirts and fake Hanson quotes: How false information spread after the Bondi attack
item.description: Misinformation and disinformation have been circulated widely since Sunday's massacre.

item.title: The PM pays tribute to the victims of the Bondi shooting | Morning News Bulletin 18 December 2025
item.description: The PM pays tribute to the victims of the Bondi shooting at a Ceremony of Remembrance, Nick Reiner is formally charged with killing his parents, director Rob Reiner and his wife Michele Singer Reiner, St Kilda's Max King expected to return to full training next year following surgery.

item.title: Nick Reiner's three-word remark as he appears in court on murder charges
item.description: If convicted as charged, Nick Reiner would face life in prison without the possibility of parole, or the ‍death penalty.

item.title: Nick Reiner's three-word remark as he appears in court on murder charges
item.description: If convicted as charged, Nick Reiner would face life in prison without the possibility of parole, or the ‍death penalty.

item.title: 'Allow the tears to come': dealing with grief after Bondi
item.description: In the wake of the Bondi beach tragedy last weekend, Sydney has welcomed new mental health support systems. New South Wales Health is offering support for anyone affected - both directly and indirectly.

item.title: Matilda, a young victim of Bondi massacre, farewelled as families offered funds
item.description: The youngest victim, 10-year-old Matilda, has been remembered as a bright and spirited girl.

item.title: Matilda, a young victim of Bondi massacre, farewelled as families offered funds
item.description: The youngest victim, 10-year-old Matilda, has been remembered as a bright and spirited girl.

item.title: Sydney man banned from Bondi over alleged antisemitic threats on Bali flight
item.description: The incident comes just days after the deadly attack on members of the Jewish community at Bondi Beach.

item.title: Sydney man banned from Bondi over alleged antisemitic threats on Bali flight
item.description: The incident comes just days after the deadly attack on members of the Jewish community at Bondi Beach.

item.title: Discrimination concerns as government flags migration reform after Bondi attack
item.description: As part of its response to the Bondi Beach attack, which claimed 15 lives, the government will review its migration settings.

item.title: Funeral for youngest victim of Bondi mass shooting | Midday News Bulletin 18 December 2025
item.description: The youngest victim of the Bondi mass shooting to be farewelled today, amid anger over the government's response to antisemitism; Fears an Australian man's been killed in Ukraine; Sam Kerr back to her big-game best.

item.title: Albanese 'failed to act' on antisemitism Ley says, as government proposes new laws
item.description: The government will accept a report from the antisemitism envoy in full and introduce a raft of new laws in the wake of the Bondi terror attack.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 18 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'We have to come together' : Multicultural communities reject division after Bondi Beach attack
item.description: Australia's social cohesion has come under scrutiny in the wake of the Bondi Beach mass shooting, while multicultural communities have come together in vigils and public acts of solidarity with Jewish Australians. The tragic mass shooting, deemed a terror attack by New South Wales Police, saw 15 people killed at a Hanukkah festival on Sunday. As leaders debate tougher laws against hate speech and extremism, Muslim and Jewish voices alike have warned against collective blame, as fears grow of a potential Islamophobic backlash.

item.title: Coping with grief after the Bondi Beach massacre: What can help in the days after tragedy
item.description: Experts say the Bondi Beach shooting can affect many, as the nervous system struggles to distinguish between perceived and actual trauma.

item.title: PM unveils five point plan to punish antisemitism | Evening News Bulletin 18 December 2025
item.description: The Prime Minister announces a five-point plan to crack down on hate in Australia; The United Nations says aid operations in Gaza are at risk of collapse; Nathan Lyon spins the third Ashes Test in Adelaide on its head.

item.title: PM introduces laws to crack down on hate speech following Bondi terrorist attack
item.description: In the wake of the Bondi Beach terrorist attack over the weekend, the Albanese government is fast-tracking a suite of legislative reforms aimed at cracking down on hate speech and tightening migration laws to avert individuals with extremist views. While the government faces pressure to introduce harsher border policies, it has rejected calls for a Royal Commission, arguing that immediate executive action and enforcement are more urgent than a lengthy public inquiry.

item.title: Australia's Christmas weather forecast has landed. Here's what to expect in your city
item.description: Before you plan a big Christmas lunch outdoors, it might be a good idea to see what the weather is looking like in your city this 25 December.

item.title: Terror at Bondi, Fragile Hope in Ukraine & Trump’s ‘WMD’ Gamble
item.description: Terror strikes the iconic sands of Bondi Beach, sending shockwaves through Australia and Jewish communities worldwide - how did the deadly attack unfold, and what does it mean for national security? Plus, Volodymyr Zelenskyy signals cautious optimism in high-stakes Ukraine peace talks but is a deal with Russia any closer? And Donald Trump brands fentanyl a ‘weapon of mass destruction’ as tensions escalate with Venezuela.

item.title: Woodside's CEO leaves for BP
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Henry Jennings from Marcus Today about the day's sharemarket action including Woodside CEO Meg O'Neill leaving for BP.

item.title: Optus failed to act on early warning signs during triple-zero outage, review finds
item.description: Optus has promised to implement 21 recommendations from an independent review into the outage that has been linked to two deaths.

item.title: Environmental laws not settled yet
item.description: Environment and business groups says work has just begun to ensure Australia's environment laws are more effective in practice. Parliament passed the first major overhaul in two decades this year, but stakeholders say the devil may be in the detail.

item.title: Concerns raise about migration vetting
AFP target 'hate preachers'
Fears of further financial pain for Australians after major banks' forecasting
item.description: The 'big four' banks have dismissed the possibility of a rate cut in 2026, raising concerns about "renewed talk" of a cost of living crisis.

item.title: The secret to a cooler home could already be sitting in your living room
item.description: Experts share how to keep cool this summer — smart home hacks, indoor greenery and safe spots for your pets, without breaking the bank.

item.title: Jewish leaders call PM’s antisemitism plan a "first step” | Morning Bulletin 19 December 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, Jewish leaders describe the Prime Minister's anti-Semitism plan as "first step"; a doctor jailed in France for poisoning patients; and in sport, the National Rugby League bans major player agents in end-of-year sanctions.

item.title: European leaders opt for loans over plan to use frozen Russian assets for Ukraine
item.description: The decision followed hours of discussions among leaders on the technical details of an unprecedented loan based on frozen Russian assets.

item.title: Trial aims to reduce dengue fever case numbers by up to 25 per cent
item.description: Researchers are hoping an early-warning system that will be trialled in Vietnam could help to reduce the growing number of dengue fever cases. Dengue fever is the world's most prevalent mosquito-borne disease and cases have been increasing across the Western Pacific and South East Asia. A computer model which will serve as an early-warning system will be rolled out across selected districts in Vietnam's Mekong Delta early next year.

item.title: More than 1,000 civilians killed in raid on Sudanese displacement camp, UN finds
item.description: A UN report has found 1,000 civilians were killed when a Sudanese paramilitary group overran a famine-stricken Darfur displacement camp.

item.title: Seven men with possible links to extremism have been released. Here's what we know
item.description: Police ruled out any links with the Bondi Beach terror attack despite concerns the men were travelling there.

item.title: National day of mourning to be held to honour victims of Bondi Beach terror attack
item.description: A day of reflection will take place this Sunday, while a national day of mourning will be held in the new year, the prime minister announced.

item.title: Albanese announces gun buyback scheme as NSW moves on gun limits, protest bans
item.description: Anthony Albanese said he expects "hundreds of thousands" of guns to be collected and destroyed through the scheme.

item.title: National Day of Reflection set for Bondi victims | Midday News Bulletin 19 December 2025
item.description: A day of reflection on the Bondi terror attack set for December 21st; Jacinta Allan confirms her husband pulled over for drink driving; The South-east Melbourne Phoenix celebrating a dramatic win in basketball.

item.title: Europe assesses risks: Using frozen Russian assets for Ukraine's war funding
item.description: European Union leaders are facing a critical decision on whether they should use frozen Russian assets to finance more support for Ukraine's war effort.

item.title: US Democrats release new Epstein images as transparency deadline nears
item.description: Congressional Democrats have released 68 new images from Jeffrey Epstein's estate, depicting people including Bill Gates and Noam Chomsky.

item.title: 'Deliberate killing of civilians': UN details deadly RSF raid on Sudan camp
item.description: A United Nations report has found Sudan’s paramilitary Rapid Support Forces killed more than 1,000 civilians during an April raid on the Zamzam displacement camp in Darfur. Based on survivor testimonies, the report documents mass executions, widespread sexual violence, torture, and the killing of aid workers. This violence has become a characteristic of the Rapid Support Forces paramilitary group which has since gone on to repeat these acts in the takeover of the nearby city of Al-Fasher.

item.title: Bondi hero Ahmed Al-Ahmed asks if he deserves $2.5 million donation
item.description: The shop owner called for unity, amid concerns over social cohesion between Australia's many communities in the wake of Bondi Beach attack.

item.title: 'Unacceptable': Victorian premier calls out teens after 200-person store raid, brawl
item.description: Police responded to almost 200 teens who swarmed a local supermarket and beach in Victoria.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 19 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Queensland to continue teen trans ban | Evening News Bulletin 19 December 2025
item.description: More details emerge about Albanese's newly announced national gun buyback; A manual vote count underway in Honduras after presidential elections in November; Melbourne City upbeat about Mathew Leckie's post-surgery return.

item.title: Gun buyback scheme to be established; Sunday will be a national day of reflection
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says his government will establish a new national gun buyback scheme, following the terror attack at Bondi Beach last Sunday. And this Sunday will see a nationwide day of reflection to remember the victims of the shooting.

item.title: Global interest rate moves influences markets
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Mahjabeen Zaman fron ANZ as the UK cuts interest rates, Japan raises them and US inflation eases more than expected, lifting the prospect of lower rates there.

item.title: The awkward new rules about to kick in for travellers to Bali
item.description: Although most tourists are unlikely to fall afoul of incoming Indonesian laws, the Australian government has warned Australians about the changes.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Wentworth MP Allegra MP says the Jewish community has been failed by Government
item.description: Allegra Spender is the independent MP representing the federal electorate of Wentworth that takes in Bondi, the scene of last Sunday's terror attack. She says she and the government have failed the Jewish Australian community and they should be moving faster to prevent hate speech. She's been speaking with SBS's Anton Enus.
